newsitem.title: JAPAN: Tokyo naphtha gains, South Korea offers Aug LSWR.
newsitem.headline: Tokyo naphtha gains, South Korea offers Aug LSWR.

text.p: Tokyo naphtha prices were higher in afternoon trade on Monday, following Friday's overseas crude oil gains, although the regional supply/demand equation remained in buyers' favour, traders said.
"There are some spot requirements here and there, but all in all Asia's fundamentals are still on the weak side," one naphtha trader said.
Open-spec naphtha, Asia's benchmark forward contract, was bid at $209.50 per tonne for first-half October delivery, while offers were heard at $211.00. It was traded at $208.00 on Friday.
In inter-month naphtha spreads, second-half September/second-half October was quoted at minus 50 cents/even. It changed hands at minus 50 cents on Friday.
A South Korean refiner said it had about 200,000 barrels of low sulphur waxy residue (LSWR) to sell for August.

The oil firm said its target price for the straight-run cargo was $1.50 per barrel over the mean of Singapore quotes, while potential buyers in Japan said it would be traded at around a $1.00 premium at best.
Japan or China was likely to be the buyer of the Korean cargo due to geographical proximity, they said.
